para.paratext: Unlike lay witnesses, experts may give opinions based upon a hypothetical set of facts.

The facts or data in the particular proceeding upon which an expert bases an opinion or inference may be those perceived by or made known to the expert at or before the hearing. If of a type reasonably relied upon by experts in the particular field in forming opinions or inferences upon the subject, such facts or data need not be admissible in evidence in order for the opinion or inference to be admitted. Such facts or data that are otherwise inadmissible shall not be disclosed to the jury by the proponent of the opinion or inference unless the court determines that their probative value in assisting the jury to evaluate the expert's opinion substantially outweighs their prejudicial effect.

An expert may testify in terms of opinion or inference and give reasons therefore without first testifying to the underlying facts or data, unless the court requires otherwise. An expert may in any event be required to disclose the underlying facts or data on cross-examination.

These two rules made some changes in prior Georgia practice. Now, O.C.G.A. §§ 24-7-703 and 24-7-705 eliminate the requirement that hypothetical questions be used but also do not prohibit their use.[1]

If counsel uses a hypothetical question, it must be based only on facts in evidence.[2] However, a hypothetical question can be based upon circumstantial evidence from which facts can be inferred even though such facts are not directly in evidence. In this situation, the jury determines if the facts have been proved and if the hypothetical opinion has a valid basis.[3] In Packer v. Gill,[4] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that circumstantial evidence can be used to prove those facts upon which an expert relies in formulating his opinion.

The hypothetical question should not include any fact not in evidence such as hearsay.[5] It does not have to include all the facts in evidence but must contain sufficient facts to justify the opinion. For example, it may include only the propounder's theory of disputed facts. It may not be based on the opinion of another witness.[6]

In Huskins v.State,[7] a witness used figures on a blackboard, which were not introduced into evidence, to illustrate his testimony. The figures were then used in a hypothetical question to an expert witness. The court said: “The method approved by the trial judge in presenting these facts to a second expert witness by allowing him to observe the facts illustrated on the blackboard by the first witness and to answer a hypothetical question based thereon was not error. In fact the method used would tend to eliminate error by being more accurate than requiring counsel to repeat the assumed facts verbally.”
Gipson v. State, 332 Ga. App. 309, 772 S.E.2d 402 (2015).

Expert witness is not permitted to give his opinion, in answer to hypothetical question, based on facts not placed in evidence by other witnesses. Horton v. Eaton, 215 Ga. App. 803, 452 S.E.2d 541 (1994) (disapproved of on other grounds by, Smith v. Finch, 285 Ga. 709, 681 S.E.2d 147 (2009)).
Horney v. Lawrence, 189 Ga. App. 376, 375 S.E.2d 629 (1988).
Packer v. Gill, 193 Ga. App. 388, 388 S.E.2d 338 (1989).

But see Woods v. Andersen, 145 Ga. App. 492, 243 S.E.2d 748 (1978), where the Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the decision to allow a hypothetical question in a wrongful death action in which an expert testified about the value of the life of a six and a half year old child and used an estimated annual inflation rate and other hearsay in answering a hypothetical question.

Ellis v. Southern Ry. Co., 89 Ga. App. 407, 79 S.E.2d 541 (1953); Zurich Ins. Co. v. Zerfass, 106 Ga. App. 714, 128 S.E.2d 75 (1962); Dix v. State, 238 Ga. 209, 232 S.E.2d 47 (1977) (need not include all material facts); Altamaha Convalescent Center, Inc. v. Godwin, 137 Ga. App. 394, 224 S.E.2d 76 (1976) (may not include facts outside of case).

In the discretion of the court, the hypothetical question may include facts to be shown later. National Trailer Convoy, Inc. v. Sutton, 136 Ga. App. 760, 222 S.E.2d 98 (1975); Sanchez v. Walker County Dept. of Family and Children Services, 138 Ga. App. 49, 225 S.E.2d 441 (1976), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 237 Ga. 406, 229 S.E.2d 66 (1976) (disapproved of on other grounds by, In Interest of R.D.F., 266 Ga. 294, 466 S.E.2d 572 (1996)); Home Ins. Co. v. Miller, 146 Ga. App. 101, 245 S.E.2d 456 (1978); Baldwin v. Walker, 143 Ga. App. 382, 238 S.E.2d 695 (1977) (cannot include facts not in evidence).

Rogers v. Eckerd Drugs of Georgia, Inc., 149 Ga. App. 788, 256 S.E.2d 130 (1979), properly held that statements of the defendant admitted for impeachment only are not substantive evidence and cannot be used to frame a hypothetical question.

Gregoroff v. State, 158 Ga. App. 363, 280 S.E.2d 373 (1981), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 248 Ga. 667, 285 S.E.2d 537 (1982), held that an objection to a hypothetical question as “not proper” was not specific enough and was properly overruled.
